Award.AwardTitle: Network Optimization of Functional Connectivity in Neuroimaging for Differential Diagnoses of Brain Diseases

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop a computational framework for identifying the critical network topology of brain connectivity in neuroimaging data, specifically functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). In this framework, network optimization modeling and mathematical programming algorithms will be employed to characterize connectivity patterns in fMRI data from different brain regions. Machine learning techniques will be employed to construct a pattern recognition model used to detect biomarkers and predict the brain disease conditions (i.e., abnormals vs. controls). An information-theoretic approach will be used to select the most informative brain regions to improve the generalizability and to increase the accuracy of the diagnosis prediction model.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improvements in efficiency and efficacy of brain functional connectivity modeling and new developments of optimization methods for handling large-scale spatio-temporal data. The developed computational framework will be extremely useful for neuroscientists and neurologists to identify abnormal functional connectivity in the brain and to gain a greater understanding of the brain function. The framework will be employed and tested as a novel biomarker for differential diagnoses of brain disorders. Alzheimer?s disease (AD), autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and Parkinson?s disease (PD) will be the case points in this project to test if our computational framework is a sensitive enough tool to detect alterations in brain connectivity associated with brain disorders. Accurate diagnosis can substantially extend a patient?s lifespan and some treatments have different outcomes at different disease stages. Additionally, the developed computational framework can be applied to other real-life large-scale spatio-temporal data that arise in other research areas such as manufacturing, medicine, bioinformatics, neuroscience, finance, and geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, three new research directions were ventured. The first direction is in the machine learning area, where new network analysis and feature selection techniques were developed to help identify critical networks in the functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) that deviate from normal connectivity. The second direction is in the combinatorial and network optimization area, where new mathematical models and mathematical programming algorithms were developed to improve the efficiency and the quality of brain network feature selection outcome. The last area is in neuroimaging and brain research, where a new machine learning framework was developed and implemented to analyze network of brain connectivity patterns that can be used in predicting control vs. brain disease (i.e., Parkinson’s and Autism Spectrum Disorder). All in all, the outcome of the project can shed lights on alterations of brain network due to the diseases and can be captured in neuroimaging data. This could lead to a development of a new machine learning paradigm for neuroimaging data that can be used to assist neurologists in recognizing abnormal patterns and/or patterns of interest of neurological diseases. This will make an impact in neuroscience/neuroimaging research as the investigation of system-level brain connectivity is still novel in the neuroimaging field and the use of network optimization to characterize patterns of local connectivity is still relatively new. 

 

This multidisciplinary project also provided training opportunities for industrial engineering and computer science students to learn about brain anatomy, neuroimaging and neurophysiology through close interactions with neurologists, radiologists and biomedical engineers who were involved in the project. Specifically, three PhD students were trained to use their diverse skills (e.g., mathematical programming, statistics, decision making, deep learning) to solve challenging problems in machine learning that arrive in the neuroimaging area. The multidisciplinary training in this project provided those students a unique training. One student took a tenure-track faculty position in healthcare engineering at SUNY Binghamton and the other student took a research scientist position at IBM Research in healthcare analytics.
